description.narrative: To provide farmers with the necessary incentives capabilities and supporting institutional framework to conserve agrobiodiversity within the farming systems of Lao PDR

Area under improved management for conservation of agrobiodiversity directly and indirectly influenced by the ABP project
Revised

comment.narrative:
300 ha accumulated
Work done in close collaboration with the TABI project A digital satellite map SPOT 6 Archive Imagery 2900 km2 have been purchased facilitating the verification of draft village land use plans including allocation of biodiversity important areas Expected to be approved by local authorities during the 3rd quarter of 2015 Other startedup biodiversity conservation activities include forest areas for wild tea and melientha trees used as vegetables The forests in these areas have been surveyed for wild tea and maps and reports are being prepared as basis for the district authorities to regulate as conservation areas The regulations together with the ongoing domestication efforts are expected to significantly reduce the unsustainable harvests in the forest

description.narrative:
GEF SP2 Tracking Tool Score for policy and regulatory frameworks
New

comment.narrative: 5 out of 5 for agriculture fisheries and forestry sectors

General
For the first time biodiversity has repeatedly been mentioned in the 8th SocioEconomic Development Plan eg output 1 of outcome 3 where biodiversity is stressed as an important element of sustainable natural resource management managed by the farmers The new research strategy of the National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute states agrobiodiversity a one of the three objectives Further the agrobiodiversity is increasingly discussed in Sector Working Group Meetings and the government encourage local government to consider to link agrobiodiversity into their sector activities
As per tracking tools the project has achieved score 2 of 6 and will increase emphasis on implementation enforcement and monitoring in the remaining period The score for these three sectors Agriculture Forestry Fishery is increased from 0 to 2 as biodiversity considerations are mentioned in sector policy and specific legislation Detailed explanations are given below
Agriculture 2 The Draft Agricultural Development Strategy ADS 2020 Shortmedium term Promote environmental friendly marketintegrated ANR growth Longterm Ensure agricultural and forestry practices are ecologically sustainable maintain production potential and quality of agricultural biodiversity Further the new Upland Development Strategy 201520 includes Biodiversity conserved for ecotourism as one of four objectives
Forestry Sector 2 The draft Agriculture Development Strategy stresses Biodiversity conserved for ecotourism and to protect and domesticate NTFPs and to protect forests
Fishery Sector 2 Fish Biodiversity is mentioned in the NBSAP and PBSAP as part of agrobiodiversity and it is agreed and acknowledged by Lao Government The government is establishing fish conservation zones in rivers as stipulated in the Fisheries Law and underpins the ongoing aquatic biodiversity conservation efforts

Agriculture Law does not incorporate emphasis on biodiversity including agrobiodiversity
Integration of biodiversity related criteria into ESIA guidelines are poor

4 accumulated
Several rounds of comments have been provided the recently approved Upland Develop Strategy added a biodiversity objective as well as its Implementation Plan
Further comments have been provided to the National Nutrition Strategy and the Environment Strategy 2020 As a result both none of them have included agrobiodiversity issues Both need formal approval
ABP project is assisting the government to preparing the second National Agrobiodiversity Programme with expected Government approval during the latter part of 2015
Finally the project will provide inputs to the 5th National Report to CBD and is in the process of startingup support to preparation of the Luang Prabang Provincial Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan

description.narrative:
Output 1: Indicators: - Policies on implementation of PM 01/2000 and related directions - Mechanisms that promote effective use of resources assigned for local administration and
Output 2: Indicators: - Plans produced by district staff to meet local priorities related to MDGs - Performance assessment of district staff linked to district service delivery targets
Output 3: Indicators: - No. of districts with capacity in planning, management & finance functions - No. of Districts receiving formula based grants - No. of Infrastructure and service interventions implemented by districts - Households benefiting from improved access to MDG services
Output 4: Indicators: - Citizen satisfaction with ODS services - Increase in speed of services - Increase in revenue collection
Output 5: Indicators: - Small grant fund to support capacity development in governance - Multi-agency partnership to manage small grant programme - Number of offices served by small grants programme
Output 6: Indicators: - Districts and provinces covered by Citizen Report Card - Districts and provinces covered by Service Delivery Monitoring System
Output 7: Indicators: - Implementation of activities in line with work plans and budgets - Reporting to Programme Board and external stakeholders - Participation of key stakeholders in oversight mechanisms

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Policies and regulatory frameworks for effective local administration at province and district level Baselines: - Budget Law 2006 offering more robust basis for district budgeting but not aligned with PM 01/2000 - Absence of performance incentives for district administrations
Output 2: Improved capacity of local administration to fulfill its service delivery mandates Baselines: - Performance evaluation of civil servants based only on job descriptions - Tools and systems yet to reflect civil servant performance in relation to district targets
Output 3: Improved MDG focused service delivery provided through formula based and equity focused block grants to the districts Baselines: - Block grants established in 35 districts for capital expenditure - Block grants piloted in 2 districts for operational expenditure
Output 4: Improving Access to Citizen Services through One Door Service Baselines: - 16 One Door Service Centres operational - Pilot Provincial Governance Info. Centre successfully tested - PMs instruction on establishing One Door Service Centres
Output 5: GPAR Capacity Development and Modernisation Fund (CADEM) supports strategic innovations in Public Administration reforms Baselines: - GPAR Fund piloted with 32 projects - Multi-agency working group manages GPAR Fund - Capacity developed and good practices replicated in 32 offices
Output 6: Citizen Feedback and district mechanisms for responsive and accountable service delivery Baselines: - Pilot Citizen Report Card complete in three provinces - Service Delivery Monitoring system piloted
Output 7: Programme support (oversight, management, coordination and results based monitoring) Baselines: - Successful GPAR projects since 1994 - PACSA/MoHA experience in managing multi-stakeholder project

Output 1: 1. Closer alignment of Sam Sang and DDF systems at local level. 2. Law on Local Administration is updated.
Output 2: 1. Local officials in 53 district have capacity to deliver priority service investments (DDF) in accordance with plans / Budgets.
Output 3: 1. 232 service interventions (21 BBG & 211 OEBG) delivered by district administrations. 2. District performance is assessed in 4 more district administrations (Sekong).
Output 4: 1. Existing ODSC operations assessed 2. ODSC operations & service delivery are improved
Output 5: 1. 13 Government offices use CADEM grants to improve their procedures. 2. 2. Gender in administrative practices is enhanced by CADEM awards.
Output 6: 1. Selected District Administrations analyse local service delivery information for use in better planning. 2. Citizens of pilot districts provide their feedback on access & quality of local service delivery.
Output 7: 1. Well-functioning & well managed project that implements activities in line with work plans and budgets 2. Project provides oversight and reporting opportunities to Programme Board and others stakeholders

Output 1: 1.Workshop discussed findings, opportunities and options on the potential for DDF to offer closer support to the Sam Sang. Ability of local administration to exercise own budget authority identified as a key factor to empower local administration to address local service priorities.
2. Local Administration law updated, approved by Government Meeting in November and ratified by National Assembly in December 2015.
Output 2: 1.1. 8 batches of DDF guidelines training and field support/backstopping organized in 2015 for DDSTs/DDSCs and MoHA staffs (399 government officials including 87 women attended the training). 1.2. Generic TOT training for 19 MoHA staff, facilitated by Public Administration Research and Training Institute (PARTI) plus follow-on TOT on DDF (DDF guidelines, PAM & M&E) for 12 MoHA staff (5 women).
Output 3: 1.1. In FY 2014-15, All 53 districts of 7 target provinces completed their district annual investment plans (DAIPs -Capital) and OEBG;LAK 7,982,898,500 (1,004,000 USD) transferred to 65 district accounts. 1.2. DAIPs of 6 selected districts for FY2015-16 approved with 16 small scale infrastructures of total LAK 2,401,233,000. ($300,154) 1.3. As part of capacity building, a total 50,500 USD transferred to 7 provinces to support the Provincial Support Team to follow up/regularly provide guidance to the district teams on DDF implementation.
2. PAM training organized for PST and the provincial assessment team of Saravane and Sekong provinces to monitor the progress of the OEBG implementation and provide M&E awareness raising. Provincial assessment teams able to carry out a district performance assessment (using District Development Fund PAM) in districts by themselves.
Output 4: 1. Concerned provincial and district service sectors shared lesson learn on service delivery and discussed on ODSC mechanism and related issues (process, service fees, human resources, revenues, etc.).
2. Service routines, office management, service mind presente

Output 1: 1. DDF lessons learnt publication produced and upgraded DDF modality is recommended to be part of the new GID which align with new local adminsitration frameworks and laws.
Output 2: 1. All of the service investments are delivered on time / budget and per mandate (DDF report for FY 2015/16).
Output 3: 1. Delivery of local service investment by DDF in 6 districts benefits from effective monitoring and oversight by 3 Provincial Support Teams
Output 4: 1. Current ODS operation assessment conducted and action plan proposed
Output 5: 1. Implementation of 13 CADEM awards are monitored and overseen
Output 6: 1. Citizens' perception of local service delivery in 2 districts is shared and lessons / best practices are considered 2. Baseline surveys on access to basic services carried out in 3 districts.
Output 7: 1. Well-functioning & well managed project that implements activities in line with work plans and budgets 2. Project provides oversight and reporting opportunities to Programme Board and others stakeholders 3. Project design for new phase of support to NGPAR is developed with stakeholders.

Output 1: Achieved; the report on DDF lessons learnt and impact was finalized on December 2016 and the DDF is part of the new GID PRODOC under Output 1.
Output 2: Achieved.
Output 3: Achieved
Output 4: Achieved; an assessment of the ODS was conducted by an international consultant and the final report, incorporating UNDP and MOHA's comments was shared with MOHA.
Output 5: Achieved.
Output 6: Achieved.
Output 7: Achieved.
The project ended in 2016 and was extended to cover the bridging period. During that time, only a few activities were organized, mainly relating to finalizing the GID PRODOC.

The project will combine improved standards in rural infrastructure with ecosystem-based adaptation at the watershed level, to contribute to the conservation of water resources and protect rural infrastructure from the impacts of climate change.

description.narrative:
Please note that this is UNDP-GEF supported project. Therefore, outcome in project document is equivalent to output in UNDP terms and outputs are activities.

description.narrative: Local administrative systems affecting the provision and maintenance of small scale rural infrastructure will be improved through participatory decision making that reflects the genuine needs of communities and natural systems vulnerable to climate risk
Percentage change in number of district development plans including specific climate change adaptation actions in the target provinces and districts AMAT 111

comment.narrative: No CC adaptation actions are in place or budgeted for in district development plans in Sekong or Saravane
50 of district development plans in the project area include at least 3 specific CCA actions by mid project and at least 5 CCA actions by end of project

Four districts have already implemented their first climate resilient infrastructure based on the District Development Fund DDF mechanism Lakhonpheng Saravane Kaleum and Lamarm districts as pilots during late 2014 and 2015 All 12 districts have prioritised climate resilience projects into their district development plans for 2015 Through a consultation with all the districts in March 2015 14 projects were prioritised for funding and implementation in 2015 All these 14 project sites were visited in June 2015 with the aim to assess their suitability for funding Based on that assessment it is anticipated that 11 out of 12 districts will implement one CCA project each in 2015 The DDF Guidelines have been revised with the aim to include climate resilience as a parameter for fund allocation to districts The revised DDF Guidelines including the fund allocation formula with the interim DVI will be applied in full to guide the district fund allocation for the climate resilience grants from the 2016 fund allocation 3rd round of funds

description.narrative: Percentage change in the level of active local community participation in climate risk related planning in target provinces and districts

comment.narrative: Although local communities in GPAR supported districts are aware of climate risks and taking part in planning decisions there is no structured process in place for analysis and integration of these risks
60 of District Development Support Committees in the target districts and provinces record specific climate related concerns emerging from community level annual planning consultations

The District Development Support Committees of all 12 districts 100 have been actively involved in the prioritising of projects for the next round of funding in 2015 14 projects have been prioritised through district consultations January March 2015 and verified through site visits together with DDSC and DDST members June 2015 Through this onthejob process local capacity for inclusion of climate resilience into district planning processes has been built

description.narrative: Capacities provided for local administrative institutions to integrate climate risks into participatory planning and financing of small scale rural water infrastructure provision
11 Percentage change in the ability of local officials to apply methodologies to analyse climate risks and identify CC vulnerabilities in 12 districts

comment.narrative: Currently no climate risk analysis is carried out made at subnational levels Some macro level VA work has been carried out eg through the SNC process but this analysis is not applicable for local level planning purposes

50 of subnational officials are able to analyse climate risks for their districts on a macro level VA analysis and are able to identify specific vulnerabilities and adaptation options at village level CRVA

Members of the DDST 5 members in 12 districts 60 technical staff have received onthejob training in climate risk planning They are expected to fully be able to analyse climate risks by Q1 of 2016 following the implementation of the CRVA A Capacity Needs Assessment CNA for local departments at provincial and district levels was implemented from SeptemberOctober 2014 and a capacity development plan was developed based on the CNA Capacity development has been mainly done through onthejob activities and associated training events such as identification and prioritisation of climate resilient infrastructure projects and ecosystem management plan development However the selection of a service provider to implement the CRVA has been a major challenge for the project During the first bidding round in OctoberNovember 2014 only one company submitted a proposal which substantially exceeded the budgetary limits of the project The ToR for the CRVA was then revised and a second bidding round initiated in February 2015 A service provider was identified in reporting period so that the CRVA can be initiated in Quarter 3 of 2015 based on which the capacity for integrating climate resilience into local planning processes will be significantly improved from late 2015 and onwards

description.narrative: 12 Procedures are in place to integrate climate change resilient advice and investment for small scale rural water infrastructure into district planning YESNO AMAT 1111

comment.narrative: No existing mechanism for climate resilient planning monitoring used for district development planning There are no linkages made between the failure of water infrastructure and the inappropriate management of ecosystems
All 12 target districts are applying a climate resilient planning mechanism including project identification site assessment approval execution and ME

With the revision of the DDF Guidelines and their expected approval by 3rd quarter of 2015 the procedures for integrating climate resilience into district planning and investments for rural water infrastructure is well underway however at the moment of reporting no target districts apply a climate resilient planning mechanism The selected CRVA service provider will include a significant element of capacity building of local authorities with the aim to facilitate this integration process The CRVA will be implemented during 2nd half of 2015

description.narrative: 13 Number of district development plans available reflecting costs for adaptation in the water sector

comment.narrative: CCA in the water sector currently not budgeted
All annual district investment plans include evidence of incremental CCA costings for water sector projects by year 4 and at least 4 provide this evidence by Year 2
11 out of 12 DDPs will include CCA projects including their costing

description.narrative: Incentives in place for small scale rural infrastructure to be protected and diversified against climate change induced risks droughts floods erosion and landslides benefitting at least 50000 people in 12 districts of Sekong and Saravane
21 Number of districts routinely investing in climate resilient measures to improve village level water harvesting storage and distribution systems

comment.narrative: Existing village level water related infrastructure is poorly maintained and not designed to cope with increasing incidence of drought flood or flash flood events

By the end of the project all target districts are investing at least 2 projects per year in village level climate resilient water harvesting storage and distribution systems which are informed by CRVA

The revised DDF Guidelines includes a climate resilience criterion that provides the incentive for integrating climate resilience into the planning process in the shortterm In the longterm the construction of climateresilient projects will provide further incentives as the benefits of doing so are documented and experienced at the local level The four pilot projects identified 2014 and implemented 2015 during the reporting period will be monitored closely within a resultsbased approach to assess impacts and demonstrate benefits from climateresilient infrastructure A baseline has been planned during the reporting period which will be implemented in quarter 3 of 2015 followed by regular collection of data and information during the remaining period of the project Similar processes for the 2nd round projects in 2015 will be implemented

description.narrative: 22 Number of people benefitting from investments in smallscale irrigation systems to increase their resilience against climate change risks AMAT 123

comment.narrative:
Climate change resilience not builtinto existing or new smallscale irrigation infrastructure
Infrastructure poorly maintained and options often not appropriate to address the real situation
At least 50000 people across 12 districts are benefitting from climate change resilient smallscale irrigation infrastructure which has been informed by CRVA

The first four pilot projects funded in 2014 and implemented within the reporting period benefit more that 4000 local villagers from the four districts of Kaleum and Lamarm in Sekong Province and Lakhonpheng and Saravane in Saravane Province The new projects for funding in 2015 possibly 12 to be confirmed will benefit approximately 12500 local people in 11 out of the 12 target districts Tum La District did not manage to identify an eligible project this year

description.narrative: 23 District level fiscal and administrative incentives are introduced that incorporate climate resilient measures for small scale rural infrastructure YESNO AMAT 1113

comment.narrative: No fiscal and administrative incentives and structures are in place to promote climate resilient planning at subnational level The existing DDF mechanism has the ability to channel baseline development funding only

At least 25 in additional CCA funds annual average expended over and above baseline District Development Funding in at least 12 districts based on a system that rewards districts that perform well against predetermined criteria
A 2nd draft of the revised DDF guidelines has been produced based on experiences of implementing the first 4 pilot projects The guidelines will be approved in 2nd half of 2015

description.narrative: Natural assets such as wetlands forests and other ecosystems in subcatchments over at least 60000 ha are managed to ensure maintenance of critical ecosystem services especially water provisioning flood control and protection under increasing climate change induced stresses in Sekong and Saravane provinces

31 Number of management action plans developed and under implementation which protect natural assets through local scale ecosystems based adaptation measures to improve the resilience of smallscale rural infrastructure against floods and drought AMAT 1219

comment.narrative: Land use and management procedures and plans supporting climate change resilience of subcatchments and smallscale rural infrastructures do not exist or if so are poorly implemented
At least 6 management and action plans covering at least 48 climate resilience smallscale infrastructure investments under implementation across both Sekong and Saravane provinces

Two 2 road maps for development management plans for the two selected areas have been developed through extensive consultations with districts and provinces January February March 2015 The starting point for the plans will be to undertake participatory landuse planning in the areas This will be done through collaboration with Department of Land Planning and Development DLPD under MONRE and their provincial and district units DLPD has a national process of parallel macrolevel and microlevel landuse planning processes going on and has already undertaken macrolevel landuse planning in Sekong Thateng district where where the Phu Ta Yeune ecosystem is situated They still need to implement microlevel ie villagebased landuse planning so this offer a good opportunity for the project to link up to the existing national process and insert climate change issues including ecosystembased adaptation as elements of the landuse planning process Eventually this offers good opportunities for upscaling of areabased climate resilience planning including ecosystembased adaptation to the national level
In terms of any additional ecosystem areas these will be selected based on the needs of existing and new infrastructure projects in order to increase integration between Project Outcome 2 and 3
The two existing ecosystem areas are both within the Sedone watershed The other major watershed in the project upper Sekong will include a number of infrastructure projects in Kaleum Dakchung and Lamarm districts and ecosystem management for ecosystembased adaptation is therefore needed in the upper Sekong watershed as well Collaboration with the ADBfunded project Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Project BCCP which include the conservation and management of approximately 170000 ha in the upper Sekong watershed in Kaleum and Dakchung districts has been tentatively initiated The project can build of activities already identified by BCCP and incorporate watershed EbA measures that in turn will also benefit the BCCP The collaboration with BCCP will be further detailed and formalised in Quarter 3 of 2015

description.narrative: 32 Number of key project stakeholders aware of links between improved ecosystem management and sustainability of investments in small scale rural water infrastructure

comment.narrative: Local planners and decision makers do not make the linkages between infrastructure investment and local land management practices There is little or no information available to planners providing a reference point or practical experience in this area

At least 250 national provincial and district planners have received knowledge and learning approaches and materials produced by the project on ecosystem based management linkages to infrastructure provision

A Capacity Needs Assessment was carried out at local level provinces and districts in October 2015 based on which a capacity development plan was developed This plan emphasises onthejob activities ie capacity development activities that are linked to project implementation This ensures a better uptake compared with conventional training sessions Training sessions targeting specific topics such as GIS modelling etc will still be considered Approximately 150 local government staff have been involved with capacity development events including members of DDST and DDSCs as well as PONRE and DONRE officers

Output 1
Indicator 1: Percentage of new NA Members (first time MNAs) that demonstrate basic skills in law making and review [using the law making manual from SPLSMP].
Indicator 2: Number of legislative briefs prepared and submitted by NA staff to the NA Committees and Members
Indicator 3: Percentage of NA Committees and Members making reference to the gender and social inclusion guidelines of the Law Making manual in their work
Output 2
Indicator 1: Number of selected NA and NA Constituency Office (NACO) staff (in 4 pilot COs) that demonstrate basic skills on research, policy analysis, archiving and data gathering techniques
Indicator 2: Number of legislative briefs submitted to NA Members by pilot constituency offices
Indicator 3: Percentage of recommendations based on the NA Capacity Development Plan including strengthening of the ICPMS unit pilot-tested
Indicator 4: Level of progress made in developing the parliamentary database (NA intranet)
*Scale of Progress from 0 to 3 points: 0 = No existing NA intranet or database in place; 1 = NA intranet/parliamentary database established; 2 = NA intranet improved and updated with selected NA staff including NACOs trained; 3 = 18 NACOs have stable ICT connection and regularly utilized the intranet for their legislation work
Output 3
Indicator 1: (i) Number of issues raised by constituents during fact-finding missions and public consultations conducted by NA Committees (ii) Percentage of constituents expressing satisfaction for the information they received during pilot public information events or "constituency office days" in selected provinces.
Indicator 2: Percentage of recommendations in the public consultation guidelines pilot-tested by the NA Committees.
Indicator 3: Level of progress in the development of an NA-stakeholders roadmap or guidelines for NA engagement with mass organizations, disadvantaged groups, NPAs and INGOs.
* Scale of Progress from 0 to 3 points: 0 = No roadmap or guideline

Output 1: 1. Achieved; 100% of new Members (109) of the National Assembly (MNAs) and Provincial Peoples Assemblies (PPAs) (360) were trained on law drafting and review. Since the Law Making Manual from SPLSMP has not been finalized and approved by MoJ, the National Assembly utilized its own law drafting and review guidelines for its own capacity building for new MNAs and PPAs.
2. Achieved; Five (5) legislative briefs were drafted by research and secretariat staff as result of the intensive training on legislative writing research and analysis provided by the NASSP Senior Technical Specialist. Topics of the legislative briefers include: (1) Ecological Conservation: The Problem of Illegal Logging in Selected Provinces; (2) Violence Against Women and their Children: Revisiting and Reviewing the Law; (3) Environmental Impact Assessments of the State of Hydro-Electric Power Industry in Lao PDR; (4) Impact Assessments of the Land Issue in Lao PDR; and (5) A Study of the Road Construction Projects in Bolikhamxay Province: Assessing its Transparency, Performance Delivery and Accountability. These legislative briefers were submitted to the relevant NA Committees for their consideration.
3. On track; Gender and social inclusion (GESI) components were integrated in the draft law making manual being developed by the UNDP SPLSMP. Quick reference briefs on gender and social inclusion were drafted by the NASSP STS and submitted to be included of the law making manual. Since the Law Making Manual from SPLSMP has not been finalized and approved by MoJ, the NA organized training workshops for MNAs and PPAs to include a presentation on GESI guidelines by the NASSP STS. Two roundtable discussions on GESI were organized by the NA Womens Caucus and the Ethnic Affairs to orient selected MNAs and line ministries on the importance of gender and social inclusion approaches in legislation.

description.narrative: 1.2.1 Availability of the national institutional mechanism for systematic capacity building of line ministries and the provincial governments on basic RBM concepts, focusing on results-based planning. 1.2.2 Extent to which policies, systems and/or institutional measures are in place at the national and sub-national levels to generate and strengthen gender-sensitive employment and livelihoods (UNDP SP Output Indicator 1.1.2). 2.1.1 Transition to the post-2020 Lao Development Forum that is fully consulted and officially adopted in line with the Vientiane Partnership Declaration (2016-2025). 2.1.2 Progress in implementation of the Vientiane Partnership Declaration Country Action Plan (2016-2025), in %. 2.2.1 Extent to which annual Round Table (Implementation) Meetings result in clear and measurable outcomes and indicators in the spirit of the Vientiane Partnership Declaration (2016-2025). 2.2.2 % of the Round Table process outcomes and indicators implemented through the Sector Working Groups and other relevant mechanisms. 3.1.1 Availability of a national roadmap for the achievement of SDGs by 2030 with costed Annual Work Plans and their implementation progress. 3.1.2 Extent to which the SDG Secretariat is able to coordinate information sharing, dialogue, engagement and cooperation on SDGs among the Government ministries/agencies, DPs, civil society and private sector in the spirit of transparency and accountability to each other. 3.2.1 Level of understanding among the central and provincial authorities of the National SDG Roadmap and their ability to contribute to its implementation. 3.2.2 Extent to which the SDG targets are integrated and implemented under the sectoral strategies/work plans with a clear financing strategy (including SWGs costed annual plans). 4.1.1 Extent to which national statistical systems allow collection of relevant data to track progress against NSEDP and localized SDGs with necessary disaggregation (UNDP CPD

comment.narrative: 1.2.1 There is no systematic training on RBM. 1.2.2 2 very partially, there has been a national policy debate and an agenda for change agreed for policies, systems and institutional measures at the national or sub-national levels to generate and strengthen employment and livelihoods. 2.1.1 In its current form, the RTP is successful but will become increasingly irrelevant post-2020. 2.1.2 VD-CAP II is developed. 2.2.1 1 not adequately; the outcomes are articulated without indicators to measure progress. 2.2.2 RTMs have stated outcomes but not systematically applied and followed up on. 3.1.1 The Prime Minister issued a decision on establishment of the National Steering Committee on SDGs under his leadership; 3.1.2 The Prime Minister issued a decision on establishment of the National Steering Committee on SDGs under his leadership; 3.2.1 1 - not adequately, general familiarity with the SDG indicators & targets exists but not on the way how to achieve them. 3.2.2 60% of 8th NSEDP indicators are linked to the SDGs, including those linked to LDC graduation. No linkage to the sectoral strategies done yet. 4.1.1 1 not adequate, LaoInfo functions reasonably well but needs further improvements and strengthening; no metadata is publicly available; horizontal exchange of data among ministries is limited; information disaggregation needs improvement. 4.1.2 LSB with the assistance from PARIS21 conducted Mid-Term Review of the Strategy 4.1.3 LSB data are used by other ministries for planning and monitoring policy implementation, however data accessibility and sharing needs improvement. 4.2.1 The 5th NDHR on LDC graduation is prepared and launched. 4.2.2 The 5th NDHR on LDC graduation is prepared and launched; The SDG Baseline Report is under preparation.

comment.narrative: 1. 1 Lao PDR INDC 2. 0 INDC Implementation Plan.
1. Dissemination on the INDC for drafting scoping of the INDC Implementation Plan preparation.
1. During this period (September to December 2015), the project is under the preparation phase.
1. Dissemination on the INDC for drafting scoping of the INDC Implementation Plan preparation.
1. Completion of one dissemination and consultation workshop for planning of the INDP implementation Plan preparation.

Output 1: 1) Two sector-specific stakeholder workshop held to support INDC implementation. 2) One strategy to address capacity gaps designed in order to strengthen institutional involvement the INDC process.
Output 2: 1) One policy advice paper. 2) One report on means of implementation identified.
Output 3: 1) 2 sector-specific stakeholder workshops including 1 high-level workshop . 2) INDC printed and disseminated. 3) 2 Training sessions for staffs in relevant line ministries and provincial and district offices conducted on the INDC and Disaster and Climate Change Law components.
Output 4: 1) 1 report with INDC implementation resources support identified. 2) 1 INDC Implementation Plan. 3) Lao PDR policies aligned with the Outcome of Paris COP21 climate agreement. 4) National institutional frameworks for INDC implementation strengthened. 5) Monitoring system identified.
Output 5: 1) 4 Quarterly and 1 Annual financial progress report prepared and submitted.
